step_overview.introduction: This step focuses on developing a clear product vision through concept design and considering environmental factors.

main_components.name: Product Concept Design
main_components.description: Develop operational, technical, and functional concepts to understand how the product will be used, what systems are needed, and what functions they'll perform.

main_components.name: Environmental Factors
main_components.description: Analyze physical (e.g., weather, working conditions) and non-physical (e.g., regulations, policies) factors that could affect the product.

subtasks.name: Operational Concept
subtasks.description: Create a flowchart showing the sequence of interactions between users and the product, identifying key interaction points.
steps: Narrow down to the main interactions

diagram.description: A flowchart representing how users interact with the product, highlighting critical interaction points.

subtasks.name: Technical Concept
subtasks.description: Describe the technical systems and subsystems needed using a hierarchical representation of the product.
steps: GPT provides preset components (e.g., wheels, frame for a bike)
GPT helps modify components based on users' needs

diagram.description: A graphical tool displaying the hierarchical structure of elements, illustrating how different components are related.

subtasks.name: Functional Concept
subtasks.description: Describe the functions that the systems will perform.
steps: Users choose parts of the technical concept to translate into a functional diagram
GPT suggests a functional concept based on the chosen components
Users review and modify the functional components as necessary

diagram.description: A graphical tool displaying the hierarchical structure of elements, illustrating how different components are related.

tasks.name: Identify and Reflect on Environmental Factors
tasks.description: Guide users to identify how environmental factors (both physical and non-physical) can impact the product.

operational: Does the diagram include main features like controls, displays, and feedback mechanisms?
Are critical user interaction points like start, stop, and adjustment clearly highlighted?
Does the diagram show how to handle common user/product errors?
Have you tested if any steps in the user flow cause confusion?
Can you simplify the diagram by removing any redundant or unnecessary steps?
Does the diagram show a logical sequence of user interactions?
technical: Have we considered any technical concept to ensure the safety of the users?
Does the technical concept have elements to handle emergency situations?
Does the diagram include basic features and functions such as controls, safety, and feedback mechanisms?
How well does the technical concept comply with relevant safety standards and regulations?
How well does the technical concept integrate with existing systems and infrastructure?
How well does the diagram cover different feature mechanisms, from prepared-to-use to maintenance and disposal?
Can the technical concept diagram scale efficiently as demand increases?
Does the diagram cover subsystems and their integration points?
functional: Does the functional concept address user needs?
Does the functional concept cover operational contexts (normal use, edge cases, and failure modes)?
Does the functional concept account for error detection and handling?
How well are the interdependencies between different functions defined?
How well does the functional concept align with user expectations for quality?
How well does the functional concept handle errors and exceptions?
Can the functional concept diagram scale efficiently as demand increases?
Does the diagram cover subsystems and their integration points?
